checker_desc: 1.检查include文件的顺序：本文件相应头文件，C系统文件，C++系统文件，其他库文件。
1. 检查符号（and、bitor、or、xor、compl、bitand、and_eq、or_eq、xor_eq、not和not_eq）的使用，建议使用（&&、/、//、^、~、&、&=、|=、^=、!、!=）代替以上几类符号。

1. 检查port前面是否使用了unsigned short修饰。如果不是，给出警告。
2. 检查是否使用了short、long、long long。如果发现使用了这些，给出警告，并建议使用int16、int64等代替之。
检查文件头是否包含Version/Module/Author标签，没有则给出告警

1. 建议编写小巧、功能集中的函数，大于50行开始给出警告，具体警告等级和代码行数关系为：50 => 0, 100 => 1, 200 => 2, 400 => 3, 800 => 4, 1600 => 5；测试代码量可以加倍。
2. 检查到函数定义，但是没有找到函数体的时候，给出警告。

1. 检查使用printf时，潜在的格式化bugs。如果发现，给出警告。
2. 当检查到snprintf函数中存在数字（size）参数时，建议使用sizeof（变量）代替数字。
3. 检查是否使用了sprintf。如果使用了，给出警告，并建议使用snprintf代替之。
4. 检查是否使用了strcpy或strcat。如果使用了，给出警告，并建议使用snprintf代替之。
该规则说明正在补充中…
检查结构体名首字母大写/小写开头，默认为大写
1. 检查是否使用了在POSIX标准中非线程安全的函数，如果使用了，给出警告。

1. 检查代码和注释之间的空格数量，建议最少空2格。如果没有，给出警告。
2. 检查在注释内容和注释符号//之间的空格。如果没有空格，给出警告。
1. 检查是否使用了static或global修饰的string常量。如果检测到了，给出警告，并建议使用C风格字符串代替。
1. 检查每一行的末尾是否有空格。如果有空格，给出警告，建议删除这些空格。

1. 检查if ... elseif ... elseif这种结构，如果其中有if或者else if使用了大括号({})，则其他的if或者else if没有使用大括号（{}），则给出警告。
2. 检查if或else体中有多条语句时，是否有大括号{}。如果没有，则给出警告。
3. 检查else是否和与之匹配的if有同样的缩进，如果没有，给出警告；同时建议用户，对于嵌套关系比较模糊的情况，使用{}标示。
4. 检查右大括号}后面是否有“;”，如果有，给出警告。PS：对于namespace、class等正确的情况，不会给出警告。
5. 检查if是否在单独一行，如果不在单独一行，给出警告。
1. 检测到有字符串分多行显示时，“...”这种连接多行字符串的方式在lint中会得到警告，建议使用C++11的raw strings或者concatenation代替。
1. 建议使用sizeof(变量)的形式
检查联合体名首字母大写/小写开头，默认为大写
1. 检查是否存在空循环体(对应for、while)。如果存在，给出警告，建议使用{}。
1. 检查是否定义了const xxx&这种类型的类数据成员。如果存在，给出警告，建议使用指针代替之。
1. 检查是否在类型转换前面使用了取址操作符。如果使用了，给出警告，因为这种用法有可能获取临时变量的地址。如以下语句就会收到警告：&down_cast<Obj*>(obj)->member_;', alt_error_msg)
检查使用usingstd; 建议使用具体命名空间，如：using std: string
检查接口函数声明是否包含virtual修饰符，且是纯虚函数，没有则给出告警

1. 检查在使用printf打印语句时，是否使用了“%qd”。如果使用了，给出警告，建议使用“%lld”。
2. 检查在使用printf打印语句时，是否使用了“%1$d”这种格式。如果使用了，给出警告。

1. 检查代码块开始处是否有空行。如果在代码块开始的时候有空行，给出警告。
2. 检查代码块结束处是否有空行。如果有空行，给出警告。
3. 检查public\protected\private后面是否有空行。如果有空行，给出警告。

1. 检查只有一个参数的构造函数是否使用了explicit关键字。如果没有使用，给出警告。
2. 检查没有参数的构造函数是否使用了explicit关键字。如果使用了，给出警告。 3. 检查有多个参数的构造函数是否使用了explicit关键字。如果使用了，给出警告。
1. 检查文件结尾是否有空白行，如果没有，提示用户添加一行空白行。
检查文件后缀名是否全部小写，没有则给出告警
1. 检查TODO注释的格式是否正确，建议格式为“// TODO(my_username): Stuff.”
1. 存储类型的关键字（static、extern、typedef、etc）应该放在其他关键词（如const、volatile、void等）前面。如果没有放到前面，给出警告。
1. 小心使用dynamic_cast<>,如果需要在类层次中使用，使用static_cast<>进行向上转型.如果虚函数足够使用，不要使用RTTI（新版本cpplint已经删除）
1. 检查文件中是否包含非法的UTF-8字符，如果存在，给出警告。
1. 检查是否使用了“>?”或者“<?”操作符。如果使用了，给出警告，并建议使用max或者min代替之。
检查文件名是否有下划线，有则给出告警
检查是否有回车符"\r"存在，有则给出告警
检查枚举是否有名称、是否以k开头，且是否符合Pascal命名规范，没有则给出告警

1. 检查每一行开始的缩进数量是否合法。如果出现奇数个缩进的情况，给出警告。建议使用2个空格缩进。
2. 结束的括号（如)、}）应该和开始的括号对齐。如果不对其，给出警告。
3. 检查public、private、protected、signals和slots的缩进是否合理。建议缩进一个空格，如果不是，给出警告。

1. 检查文件中是否有未知的NOLINT错误分类
2. 检查未知的分类GLOBAL_NOLINT；
检查OneSDK头文件是否使用#ifndef...#define进行保护，没有则给出告警
1. 检查是否使用了未定义的字符转义序列，如\%,\[,\(和\{。如果检查到这些转义序列，给出警告。
1. 检查是否使用变量来初始化数组。如果发现了，给出警告，并建议使用编译时常量来初始化数组。
检查接口名称首字母大写，且以I开头，没有则给出告警
1.检查#endif后面是否跟有注释，如果没有注释，给出警告。

1. 检查函数名和开始的括号(之间是否有空格，如果有空格，给出警告。
2. 检查函数的结束括号)是否和函数名在同一行上。如果不在同一行，在下一行的话给出警告。
3. 检查函数的结束括号）前面是否有空格，如果有空格，给出警告。
4. 检查if\for\while\switch和开始的括号(之间是否有空格，如果没有空格，给出警告。
5. 检查if\for\while\switch后面的括号()之间的空格是否对称。如果不对称。给出警告（如if( foo )这种情况）。
6. 检查if\for\while\switch后面的括号()内侧的空格情况，建议可以有0个或者1个空格。如果不是0个或者1个，给出警告。
检查大括号“{”不单独占一行，如果单独占一行，则告警。
1. 检查每一行代码的长度。对于长度超过120个字符的，给出较严重警告；对于长度超过100个字符的，给出较低级别警告。
1. 检查文件中是否存在'\0'字符，即NUL字符，如果存在，给出警告。
检查结构体名称、成员命名是否符合Pascal规范

1. 检查namespace的结束位置是否有注释，注释格式为namespace“//namespace xxx”。
2. 检查匿名namespace的结束位置注释是否合法，注释格式应该为“//namespace”或者“//anonymous namespace”
1. 检查if语块是否有效，是否有else分支，如果没有，给出警告。

1. 多行注释，如果没有搜索到注释结束标识符，给出警告。
2. 检测到了多行注释/* */，lint工具可能会对此给出警告，建议使用//代替之。

1. 检查“=”号两边是否有空格。如果没有，给出警告。
2. 检查“==|!=|<=|>=||”双目运算符两边是否有空格。如果没有，给出警告。
3. 检查“<|>|<<|>>|!|~|--|++”等单目运算符两边是否有空格。如果没有，给出警告。
4. 检查“&&”两边是否有空格。如果没有，给出警告。
1. 检查函数参数是否是不含参数名称的参数,如果是,给出警告.(如void test(int)会给出警告)
1. 检查是否有使用（*++、*--）的情况。如果使用了这种情况，给出警告，提示这种情况会同时改变指针的位置。
1. 在逗号“,”之后需要有空格。如果没有，给出警告。
检查函数名称是否符合Pascal命名规范，没有则给出告警
1. 检查是否重载了操作符&。如果重载了，鉴于该操作符的危险性，给出警告。

1.检查对C++11标准提到的右值引用的使用，如果检查到使用右值引用，给出警告（未批准的C++特性）。
2. 检查是否使用了默认的lambda捕获，如果使用了，给出警告（未批准的C++特性）。
3. 检查是否include了未批准的C++特性的头文件，如cfenv、condition_variable等。如果检查到了，给出警告。
4. 检查是否使用了std: : alignment_of或std: : aligned_union，如果使用了，给出警告。
检查接口是否有virtual析构函数，没有则给出告警
该规则说明正在补充中…

1. 检查“[”符号前面是否有空白。如果有，给出警告。
2. 检查“{”符号前面是否留有空白。如果没有，给出警告。
3. 检查“}else”这种情况的else前面是否留有空白。如果没有，给出警告。
4. 检查“{”是否接在语句最后，即“{”是否直接跟在语句的后面，而不是单独起一行。如果单独占一行，给出警告。
1. 检查是否在namespace中存在缩进。如果有，给出警告。

1. 检查宏DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN和DISALLOW_IMPLICIT_CONSTRUCTORS的作用域是否正确，正确的作用域为private。
2. 检查宏DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN和DISALLOW_IMPLICIT_CONSTRUCTORS的位置是否正确，正确的位置是在类的结束位置。
1. 在函数的后面如果有关键字final或者overrider，表示该函数不可以为虚函数，如果检查到final或overrider修饰的函数有virtual修饰，会给出警告。
1. 检查memset是否有书写错误。如果检查到类似于memset(buf, sizeof(buf), 0)，则是一个潜在的memset bug，给出警告。
1. 检查文中是否使用了Tab。如果使用了，给出警告，建议使用空格代替。
1. 建议不要使用流（google  C++编程规范条目），新版本cpplint已经不支持对此条目的检查。
1.检查是否使用了未经批准的C++TR1头文件，如果使用了，给出警告。
1. 检查for循环中冒号前后是否有空格，如果没有，给出警告。
检查枚举名首字母大写/小写开头，默认为大写
1. 检查是否存在使用变量自身初始化自己的情况。如果存在这种情况，给出警告。
1.在作用域内（如namespace作用域），检查是否使用了类似“class AA: : tt;”这种格式的前向声明。如果有这种前向声明，给出警告。

1. 检查一行上是否有多条语句。如果出现，给出警告。
2. 检查else语句的位置，建议和}在一行上。如果不在一行上，给出警告。
3. 检查是否出现“else{”这种语句。如果出现，给出警告，建议将{放到下一行。
4. 检查{是否和do\while在同一行上。如果出现，给出警告，建议将{放到下一行。
5. 检查在换行的时候，是否使用了回车\r。如果使用了，给出警告，建议使用\n换行。
检查枚举名称是否全部大写，或以下划线分隔，没有则给出告警
检查OneSDK头文件是否以namepace Gcloud{}包括，没有则给出告警
1.为了C++11的兼容性，省略make_pair中的模板参数，或者直接使用pair，或者直接构造一个pair。如果检测到make_pair中使用了模板参数，给出警告。

1. 检查命名空间定义是否有结束标记，如果没有，给出警告。
2. 检查是否使用了using编译指令，如果使用了，给出警告，提示用户使用using声明指令。
3. 检查在.h文件中是否使用了不具名的命名控件，如果使用了，给出警告。
1. 检查是否存在空条件体（对应于if）。如果存在，给出警告，建议使用{}。
1.检查相同目录下头文件是否按字母序升序引用，如果没有，给出警告。

1.对基本类型，检查是否使用了过时的类型转换，建议使用static_cast()代替(type)这种转换方式。检查的类型有：int,float,double,bool,char,int32,uint32,int64,uint64.
2. 检查是否在类型转换前面使用了取址操作符。如果使用了，给出警告。如以下语句就会收到警告：&down_cast(obj)->member_;', alt_error_msg)
检查文件名首字母是否大写，没有则给出告警
检查{是否另起一行，没有则给出告警
1.检查类声明是否完整，即类声明的结束部位是否含有“}”。如果没有，给出类声明不完整警告。
1. 检查文件中是否包含“Copyright [year]<Copyright Owner>”，如果不包含，给出警告。
1.检查是否添加必要的标准模版库，如果没有，给出警告。

1. 在分号“;”之后需要有空格。如果没有，给出警告。
2. 检查使用分号“;”表示空状态的语句。如果检查到了，给出警告，并提示使用{}代替。
3. 检查每行最后一个分号“;”，看其前面是否有空格。如果有空格，给出警告。
1. VLOG()接受数值等级参数，如果使用符号等级参数，请使用LOG()

1.检查每一个C++源文件是否都有一个对应的.h头文件，如果没有，给出警告。
2. 检查include的头文件是否加上路径，如果没有，给出警告。
3. 检查是否include了多次同一个头文件，如果是，给出警告。
4. 不要include其他包里面的.cc文件。如果include了，给出警告。
1.检查ASSERT和CHECK断言的使用，建议使用ASSERT_EQ和CHECK_EQ等方式，而不是使用ASSERT_TRUE(condition)这种形式。
1.检查是否使用了未经批准的C++14头文件，如果使用了，给出警告。

1.检查两点: (1)头文件中是否含有#ifndef、#define，(2)#ifndef和#define中的内容是否一样。如果上述两条有一条满足，给出警告。
2. 检查#ifndef的格式是否正确，正确的命名格式是：PATH_FILE_H_。如果格式有出入，给出警告。
3. 检查#endif的格式是否正确，正确的格式是#endif // PATH_FILE_H_。如果不满足这种格式，给出警告。
4. 对上一点3的补充检查：检查#endif后面的注释，如果没有/* */或者//...格式注释，给出警告。
1. 检查TODO注释前后的空格数量，如果没有空格，会给出警告；如果多余1个空格，也给出警告。
1. 在函数参数中，查找是否使用了非const型的指针。如果发现了这种类型的指针，则给出警告，并建议使用const型或者指针代替之。
检查类名首字母大写/小写开头，默认为大写
检查头文件是否使用了using namespace，有则给出告警
Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary whose keys are not all strings.

Used when a bare raise is not used inside an except clause. This generates an error, since there are no active exceptions to be reraised. An exception to this rule is represented by a bare raise inside a finally clause, which might work, as long as an exception is raised inside the try block, but it is nevertheless a code smell that must not be relied upon.
Used when from module import * is detected.

Used when the body of a lambda expression is a function call on the same argument list as the lambda itself; such lambda expressions are in all but a few cases replaceable with the function being called in the body of the lambda.
Used when multiple consecutive isinstance calls can be merged into one.
Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary that doesn't contain all the keys required by the format string.
The method is marked as deprecated and will be removed in a future version of Python. Consider looking for an alternative in the documentation.
Used when another argument than the current class is given as first argument of the super builtin.
Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but no assignment to this variable is done.
Used a module marked as deprecated is imported.
Some inline pylint options have been renamed or reworked, only the most recent form should be used. NOTE:skip-all is only available with pylint >= 0.26
Used when a wrong number of spaces is used around an operator, bracket or block opener.
Used when an instance attribute is defined outside the init method.
Emitted when the keys of a dictionary are iterated through the .keys() method. It is enough to just iterate through the dictionary itself, as in "for key in dictionary".
Used when a method signature is different than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method.
Used when class has too many parent classes, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.
Used when assigning to an attribute not defined in the class slots.
Used when an inline option disables a message or a messages category.
Used when an abstract method (i.e. raise NotImplementedError) is not overridden in concrete class.
Used when a function call passes too few arguments.
Emitted when a conditional statement (If or ternary if) uses a constant value for its test. This might not be what the user intended to do.
Used when a PEP 3101 format string that uses named fields is used with an argument that is not required by the format string. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.
Used when a static method is defined without using the decorator syntax.
Used when an len method returns something which is not a non-negative integer

Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.method>(format_string.format(format_args...))". Such calls should use % formatting instead, but leave interpolation to the logging function by passing the parameters as arguments.
Used when an imported module or variable is not used from a 'from X import *' style import.
Used when a function or method takes too many arguments.
Used when the name is listed in the black list (unauthorized names).
Used when an unexpected error occurred while building the Astroid representation. This is usually accompanied by a traceback. Please report such errors !
Used when a class has no init method, neither its parent classes.
Used when a syntax error is raised for a module.
Emitted when a function call got multiple values for a keyword.
Used when a non-iterable value is used in place where iterable is expected
Indicates that a set of similar lines has been detected among multiple file. This usually means that the code should be refactored to avoid this duplication.
Used when a function or method has too many return statement, making it hard to follow.
Used when a statement doesn't have (or at least seems to) any effect.
Used when you attempt to use the C-style pre-increment orpre-decrement operator -- and ++, which doesn't exist in Python.
Used when except clauses are not in the correct order (from the more specific to the more generic). If you don't fix the order, some exceptions may not be caught by the most specific handler.
Used when PEP8 import order is not respected (standard imports first, then third-party libraries, then local imports)
Used when an exception occured while building the Astroid representation which could be handled by astroid.
Used when a cyclic import between two or more modules is detected.
Used when a boolean expression contains an unneeded negation.
Used when a unsupported format character is used in a format string.

Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.(format_string % (format_args...))". Such calls should leave string interpolation to the logging method itself and be written "logging.(format_string, format_args...)" so that the program may avoid incurring the cost of the interpolation in those cases in which no message will be logged. For more, see http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0282/.
Used when a variable is accessed for an unexistent member.
Used when a word in docstring is not spelled correctly.

Used when a local name is redefining an argument, which might suggest a potential error. This is taken in account only for a handful of name binding operations, such as for iteration, with statement assignment and exception handler assignment.
Used when a non-mapping value is used in place where mapping is expected
Used when a function or method argument is not used.

Emitted when a with statement component returns multiple values and uses name binding with as only for a part of those values, as in with ctx() as a, b. This can be misleading, since it's not clear if the context manager returns a tuple or if the node without a name binding is another context manager.
Used when an object being called has been inferred to a non callable object
The argument to a str.{l,r,}strip call contains a duplicate character,
Used when an undefined variable is accessed.
Used when comparing an object to a literal, which is usually what you do not want to do, since you can compare to a different literal than what was expected altogether.
Emitted when there are more than one starred expressions (*x) in an assignment. This is a SyntaxError. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when an inline option is either badly formatted or can't be used inside modules.
Emitted when an object does not support item assignment (i.e. doesn't define setitem method)
Emitted when a nonlocal variable does not have an attached name somewhere in the parent scopes This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when you use the "global" statement to update a global variable. Pylint just try to discourage this usage. That doesn't mean you cannot use it !
Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function returns nothing but None.
Used when a function or method has too many branches, making it hard to follow.
Used when a bad value for an inline option is encountered.
Used when an loop variable (i.e. defined by a for loop or a list comprehension or a generator expression) is used outside the loop.
Emitted whenever we can detect that a class is using, as a metaclass, something which might be invalid for using as a metaclass.
Python supports: r, w, a[, x] modes with b, +, and U (only with r) options. See http://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html#open
Used when NotImplemented is raised instead of NotImplementedError
A variable used in a closure is defined in a loop. This will result in all closures using the same value for the closed-over variable.
Used when a "pass" statement that can be avoided is encountered.
Used when an expression is compared to singleton values like True, False or None.
Used when a variable's name hide a name defined in the outer scope.
Used when an abstract class with abc.ABCMeta as metaclass has abstract methods and is instantiated.
Used when a function call does not pass a mandatory keyword-only argument. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Emitted when a subscripted value doesn't support subscription(i.e. doesn't define getitem method)
Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but the variable is not defined in the module scope.
Used when a function call would result in assigning multiple values to a function parameter, one value from a positional argument and one from a keyword argument.

Used when a format string contains both named (e.g. '%(foo)d') and unnamed (e.g. '%d') conversion specifiers. This is also used when a named conversion specifier contains * for the minimum field width and/or precision.
Used whenever we can detect that an overridden method is useless, relying on super() delegation to do the same thing as another method from the MRO.
Used when an except clause doesn't specify exceptions type to catch.
Used when an except catches a type that was already caught by a previous handler.
Used when there is some code behind a "return" or "raise" statement, which will never be accessed.
Used when a variable is defined but not used.
Used when a sequence type is indexed with an invalid type. Valid types are ints, slices, and objects with an index method.
Emitted when the continue keyword is found inside a finally clause, which is a SyntaxError.

Used when a metaclass class method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "mcs"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.
Used when a class has duplicate bases.
Used when a PEP 3101 format string that uses named fields doesn't receive one or more required keywords. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.
Used when a logging statement format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.
Emitted when an instance in membership test expression doesn't implement membership protocol (contains/iter/getitem)
Wrong continued indentation before block (add 4 spaces)
Used when you use the "eval" function, to discourage its usage. Consider using ast.literal_eval for safely evaluating strings containing Python expressions from untrusted sources.
Emitted when code that iterates with range and len is encountered. Such code can be simplified by using the enumerate builtin.
Used when a method has an attribute different the "self" as first argument. This is considered as an error since this is a so common convention that you shouldn't break it!
Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with an argument that is not a mapping.
Used when there are mixed (LF and CRLF) newline signs in a file.
Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given too many arguments.
Used when a logging format string is given too few arguments.
Used when an invalid slots is found in class. Only a string, an iterable or a sequence is permitted.
Used when a if statement contains too many boolean expressions
Used when a word in comment is not spelled correctly.
Used when an unknown inline option is encountered.
Used when a module is importing itself.
Used when the exception to catch is of the form "except A or B:". If intending to catch multiple, rewrite as "except (A, B):"
Used when an inline option enables a message or a messages category.
Used when a backslash is in a literal string but not as an escape.
Used when a word in docstring cannot be checked by enchant.
Used when Pylint detects incorrect use of len(sequence) inside conditions.
Used when a method has a different number of arguments than in the implemented interface or in an overridden method.
Used when an undefined variable name is referenced in all.
The first argument of assertTrue and assertFalse is a condition. If a constant is passed as parameter, that condition will be always true. In this case a warning should be emitted.
Used when there is different newline than expected.
Used when a function or method has too many statements. You should then split it in smaller functions / methods.
Used when the special class method init has an explicit return value.
Used when an ancestor class method has an init method which is not called by a derived class.
Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given too few arguments
Used when an if statement can be replaced with 'bool(test)'.
Used when a variable or function override a built-in.
Used when a class which doesn't inherit from Exception is used as an exception in an except clause.
Used when an instance in a with statement doesn't implement the context manager protocol(enter/exit).
Used when an expression that is not a function call is assigned to nothing. Probably something else was intended.
Used when there is an unbalanced tuple unpacking in assignment
Python 2.5 and greater require future import to be the first non docstring statement in the module.
Used when Pylint has been unable to check methods signature compatibility for an unexpected reason. Please report this kind if you don't make sense of it.
Used when there are some mixed tabs and spaces in a module.
Used when something which is neither a class, an instance or a string is raised (i.e. a TypeError will be raised).
Used when a relative import tries to access too many levels in the curren package.
Used when pylint has been unable to import a module.

In Python, a tuple is actually created by the comma symbol, not by the parentheses. Unfortunately, one can actually create a tuple by misplacing a trailing comma, which can lead to potential weird bugs in your code. You should always use parentheses explicitly for creating a tuple. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with a dictionary that contains keys not required by the format string.
Used when a format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.
Used when an imported module or variable is not used.
Used when a class slots is a simple string, rather than an iterable.
Reported when a message is explicitly disabled for a line or a block of code, but never triggered.
he idiomatic way to perform an explicit typecheck in Python is to use isinstance(x, Y) rather than type == Y, type is Y. Though there are unusual situations where these give different results.
Used when a single item in parentheses follows an if, for, or other keyword.
Used when a method doesn't use its bound instance, and so could be written as a function.
Used when a class defines a method which is hidden by an instance attribute from an ancestor class or set by some client code.
A call of assert on a tuple will always evaluate to true if the tuple is not empty, and will always evaluate to false if it is.
Emitted when a star expression is not used in an assignment target. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when something which is not a sequence is used in an unpack assignment
Used when you use the "exec" statement (function for Python 3), to discourage its usage. That doesn't mean you cannot use it !
Used to inform that a built-in module has not been checked using the raw checkers.
Used when a "yield" statement is found outside a function or method.
Emitted when a name is both nonlocal and global. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException is raised.
Used when a function call passes too many positional arguments.
Used when a PEP 3101 format string contains both automatic field numbering (e.g. '{}') and manual field specification (e.g. '{0}'). This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.
Used when a mutable value as list or dictionary is detected in a default value for an argument.
Used when an instance member is accessed before it's actually assigned.
used when an error occurred preventing the analysis of a module (unable to find it for instance).
Used when a class method is defined without using the decorator syntax.
Used when code and imports are mixed
Used when a line is longer than a given number of characters.
Emitted when a star expression is used as a starred assignment target. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when the first argument to reversed() builtin isn't a sequence (does not implement reversed, nor getitem and len
Used when an unsupported format character is used in a logging statement format string.
Used when a module, function, class or method has no docstring.Some special methods like init doesn't necessary require a docstring.
Used when an except catches a too general exception, possibly burying unrelated errors.
Used when imports are not grouped by packages
Used when the name doesn't match the regular expression associated to its type (constant, variable, class...).
Duplicate argument names in function definitions are syntax errors.
Used when a function or a method has too many nested blocks. This makes the code less understandable and maintainable.
Used when import statement importing multiple modules is detected.
Used when an exception handler assigns the exception to an existing name
Used when a statement is ended by a semi-colon (";"), which isn't necessary (that's python, not C ;).
Used when the last line in a file is missing a newline.
Used when a module has too much lines, reducing its readability.
A message was triggered on a line, but suppressed explicitly by a disable= comment in the file. This message is not generated for messages that are ignored due to configuration settings.
Used when using the syntax "raise ... from ...", where the exception context is not an exception, nor None. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.
Used when a string is used as a statement (which of course has no effect).
Used when one of known pre-python 2.5 ternary syntax is used.
Used when an escape like \u is encountered in a byte string where it has no effect.
Used when a static method has "self" or a value specified in valid- classmethod-first-arg option or valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option as first argument.
Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in all.
Used when a class has an inconsistent method resolution order.
Emitted when a unary operand is used on an object which does not support this type of operation
Used when a class inherits from something which is not a class.
Used when an unexpected number of indentation's tabulations or spaces has been found.
Loops should only have an else clause if they can exit early with a break statement, otherwise the statements under else should be on the same scope as the loop itself.
Used when a local variable is accessed before it's assignment.
Used when a protected member (i.e. class member with a name beginning with an underscore) is access outside the class or a descendant of the class where it's defined.
Used when the special class method init is turned into a generator by a yield in its body.
Used when a module is reimported multiple times.
Used when a break or a return statement is found inside the finally clause of a try...finally block: the exceptions raised in the try clause will be silently swallowed instead of being re-raised.
Emitted when a special method was defined with an invalid number of parameters. If it has too few or too many, it might not work at all.
Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred function doesn't return anything.
Emitted when an object does not support item deletion (i.e. doesn't define delitem method)
Used when you use the "global" statement at the module level since it has no effect
Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in slots.
Used when a method which should have the bound instance as first argument has no argument defined.
Used when there are trailing blank lines in a file.
Used when class has too many instance attributes, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.
Used when an iter method returns something which is not an iterable (i.e. has no __next__ method)
Used when break or continue keywords are used outside a loop.
Used to inform that the file will not be checked
Used when a PEP 3101 format string is invalid. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.
Used when class has too few public methods, so be sure it's really worth it.
Used when a dictionary expression binds the same key multiple times.
Used when a "return" statement is found outside a function or method.
Used when a slice index is not an integer, None, or an object with an index method.
Emitted when a binary arithmetic operation between two operands is not supported.
Used when an init method is called on a class which is not in the direct ancestors for the analysed class.
Used when a name cannot be found in a module.
Used when there is whitespace between the end of a line and the newline.

Used when a PEP 3101 format string uses a lookup specifier ({a[1]}), but the argument passed for formatting doesn't contain or doesn't have that key as an attribute. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.
Used when a logging format string is given too many arguments.
Used when class has too many public methods, try to reduce this to get a simpler (and so easier to use) class.

Used in order to highlight an unnecessary block of code following an if containing a return statement. As such, it will warn when it encounters an else following a chain of ifs, all of them containing a return statement.
Used when a warning note as FIXME or XXX is detected.
Used when a function or method has too many local variables.
Used when a function / class / method is redefined.
Used when a function call passes a keyword argument that doesn't correspond to one of the function's parameter names.
Used when a module, function, class or method has an empty docstring (it would be too easy ;).

Used when a class method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.
Used when an yield or yield from statement is found inside an async function. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.5.
Used when a PEP 3101 format string uses an attribute specifier ({0.length}), but the argument passed for formatting doesn't have that attribute. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 2.7.
Used when more than on statement are found on the same line.
Used when the constant is placed on the left side of a comparison. It is usually clearer in intent to place it in the right hand side of the comparison.
Used when an async context manager is used with an object that does not implement the async context management protocol. This message can't be emitted when using Python < 3.5.

Used when a metaclass method has a first argument named differently than the value specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

checker_desc: io.Writer.Write 不能修改所提供的buffer缓冲区，即使是临时性的

checker_desc:
1、比较两个不同长度的字符串是否相等，会永远返回false；
2、无符号数不可能 < 0；
3、无符号数永远 >= 0；
4、x %s 0的结果永远等于x；
5、没有数值等于NaN，即使Nan本身；
6、x & 0的结果永远等于 0；
checker_type_desc: 静态检测bug，包括明显的bug和比较微妙的bug

checker_desc: goroutine调用T.%s，作为测试test必须在相同的goroutine里调用

checker_desc: finalizer closes over the object, preventing the finalizer from ever running (at %s)
checker_type_desc: 静态检测bug，包括明显的bug和比较微妙的bug

checker_desc: 函数参数的首字母需要小写

checker_type_desc: Google的linter，侧重于代码风格

checker_desc:
1、%s 名称会被其他packages以 %s.%s引用，可以考虑这样调用 %s；
2、error变量%s应该以%sFoo形式命名；
3、Go名称不应该使用全部大写，请使用驼峰格式；
4、Go名称不应该使用k开头；%s %s应该是%s；
5、%s %s 应该是 %s；
6、receiver名称不应该有下划线，如果是不使用的，可以省略；
7、receiver名称应该是其身份的反射；不要使用this或者self；
8、receiver名称%s应该与之前的%s %s保持一致；
9、Go名称不应该使用下划线；%s %s应该是%s；
checker_type_desc: Google的linter，侧重于代码风格

checker_desc:
1、应该转换 %s(类型为%s）到%s，而不是使用struct结构；
2、应该使用 for {} 而不是 for true {}；
3、不必要的nil检查；
4、应该使用原生字符串 (`...`)及regexp.%s避免转义两次；
5、应该使用无条件的 %s.%s 来替换这个if语句；
6、当 %s 为true时，%s不可能为nil；
7、应该写 %s 而不是 %s；
8、应该在新的一行里合并变量的声明和赋值；
9、多余的break语句；
10、应该使用fmt.Errorf(...)，而不是errors.New(fmt.Sprintf(...))；
11、应该省略nil检查；%s执行len()定义为0；
12、应该使用%s = append(%s, %s...) 来替换循环；
13、使用slice时应该省略第二个index，s[a:len(s)] 等效于 s[a:]；
14、应该使用time.Util，而不是t.Sub(time.Now())；
15、应该使用%v.String()方法而不是%v；
16、if %s != nil { return %s }; return %s' 可以简化为 'return %s'；
17、'_ = <-ch' 可以简化为 '<-ch'；
18、应该使用 'return '，而不是 'if { return }; return '；
19、应该使用String()，而不是fmt.Sprintf；
20、应该使用%v.Bytes()方法而不是%v；
21、应该使用 %s%s.%s(%s)；

Catching java.lang.Exception, java.lang.Error or java.lang.RuntimeException is almost never acceptable.

Checks that a local variable or a parameter does not shadow a field that is defined in the same class.

Checks the header of a java source file against a header that contains a regular expression for each line of the source header.

The Check validate abbreviations(consecutive capital letters) length in identifier name, it also allow in enforce camel case naming.

This check calculates the Non Commenting Source Statements (NCSS) metric for Java source files and methods.
Checks the padding of an empty for iterator; that is whether a space is required at an empty for iterator, or such spaces are forbidden.
Check that finds import statements that use the * notation.
Checks line wrapping for operators.

Checks the distance between declaration of variable and its first usage.

Checks for long source files.

Checks for the number of defined types at the "outer" level.
Checks cyclomatic complexity against a specified limit.
Implements Bloch, Effective Java, Item 17 - Use Interfaces only to define types.
Ensures there is a package declaration and (optionally) in the correct directory.
Checks if array initialization contains optional trailing comma.

Checks for redundant modifiers in interface and annotation definitions, final modifier on methods of final classes, inner interface declarations that are declared as static, non public class constructors and enum constructors, nested enum definitions that are declared as static.
Checks the npath complexity against a specified limit (default = 200).
Checks that parameter names conform to a format specified by the format property.
Checks for illegal token text.
Checks for blank line separators.
Reports empty for loops.
To compare an object with null prefer using ==. This rule detects and reports instances in the code where the equals() method is used to compare a value with null.
This rule detects functions that only returns a single constant. Instead prefer to define the constant directly as a const val.
Reports function parameter names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.

"This rule reports functions inside data classes which have not been whitelisted as a conversion function.Data classes should mainly be used to store data. This rule assumes that they should not contain any extra functions aside functions that help with converting objects from/to one another. Data classes will automatically have a generated equals, toString and hashCode function by the compiler."

This rule reports all exceptions which are thrown without arguments or further description. Exceptions should always call one of the constructor overloads to provide a message or a cause. Exceptions should be meaningful and contain as much detail about the error case as possible. This will help to track down an underlying issue in a better way.
Reports when package names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.

This rule reports postfix expressions (++, –-) which are unused and thus unnecessary. This leads to confusion as a reader of the code might think the value will be incremented/decremented. However the value is replaced with the original value which might lead to bugs.
Reports all return statements in finally blocks. Using return statements in finally blocks can discard and hide exceptions that are thrown in the try block.

Verifies implementations of the Iterator interface. The hasNext() method of an Iterator implementation should not have any side effects. This rule reports implementations that call the next() method of the Iterator inside the hasNext() method.
This rule verifies spacing between package and import statements as well as between import statements and class declarations.
This rule reports abstract modifiers which are unnecessary and can be removed.
Reports when very short variable names are used.
Reports when class or object names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.

let expressions are used extensively in our code for null-checking and chaining functions, but sometimes their usage should be replaced with a ordinary method/extension function call to reduce visual complexity
This rule allows to define functions which should never throw an exception. If a function exists that does throw an exception it will be reported.
Kotlin classes are final by default. Thus classes which are not marked as open should not contain any protected members. Consider using private or internal modifiers instead.
Requires that the equals sign, when used for an expression style function, is on the same line as the rest of the function signature.
Functions which only contain a return statement can be collapsed to an expression body.
Reports functions which have more parameters than a certain threshold.
This rule reports if tabs are used in Kotlin files.
This rule reports excessive nesting depth in functions.
Reports when function names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.
This rule detects and reports usages of magic numbers in the code. Prefer defining constants with clear names describing what the magic number means.
This rule reports complex interfaces which contain too many functions and/or properties.
Reports empty else blocks.
Reports when enum names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.
This rule reports unused imports.

It is not necessary to define a return type of Unit on functions or to specify a lone Unit statement. This rule detects and reports instances where the Unit return type is specified on functions and the occurrences of a lone Unit statement.
Nested classes are often used to implement functionality local to the class it is nested in. Therefore it should not be public to other parts of the code. Prefer keeping nested classes private.
Using a spread operator causes a full copy of the array to be created before calling a method. This has a very high performance penalty.
This rule detects and reports duplicated String literals.

"Flags duplicate case statements in when expressions.If a when expression contains the same case statement multiple times they should be merged. Otherwise it might be easy to miss one of the cases when reading the code, leading to unwanted side effects."
This rule reports cases in the code where modifiers are not in the correct order.
Reports when very short function names are used.
This rule reports thrown exceptions that have a type that is too generic. It should be preferred to throw specific exceptions to the case that has currently occurred.

"Wildcard imports should be replaced with imports using fully qualified class names. This helps increase clarity of which classes are imported and helps prevent naming conflicts.Library updates can introduce naming clashes with your own classes which might result in compilation errors."
This rule reports unnecessary super types. Inheriting from Any or Object is unnecessary and should simply be removed.
This rule reports all exceptions that are thrown in a main method. An exception should only be thrown if it can be handled by a “higher” function.

This rule reports catch blocks which check for the type of an exception via is checks or casts. Instead of catching generic exception types and then checking for specific exception types the code should use multiple catch blocks. These catch blocks should then catch the specific exceptions.

This rule inspects abstract classes. In case an abstract class does not have any concrete members it should be refactored into an interface. Abstract classes which do not define any abstract members should instead be refactored into concrete classes.
This rule validates the end of the first sentence of a KDoc comment.

Reports calls to ‘..’ operator instead of calls to ‘until’. ‘until’ is applicable in cases where the upper range value is described as some value subtracted by 1. ‘until’ helps to prevent off-by-one errors.
Reports empty default constructors.
Reports empty do/while loops.

This rule reports labeled expressions. Expressions with labels generally increase complexity and worsen the maintainability of the code. Refactor the violating code to not use labels instead. Labeled expressions referencing an outer class with a label from an inner class are allowed, because there is no way to get the instance of an outer class from an inner class in Kotlin.
This rule reports lines that end with a whitespace.
Reports when very long variable names are used.
Reports unused private classes.
This rule reports lines of code which exceed a defined maximum line length.
Exceptions should not be swallowed. This rule reports all instances where exceptions are caught and not correctly passed into a newly thrown exception.
Reports when property names inside objects which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.
This rule detects multi-line if statements which do not have braces. Adding braces would improve readability and avoid possible errors.
Restrict the number of return methods allowed in methods. Having many exit points in a function can be confusing and impacts readability of the code.
Reports equals() methods which will always return true or false.

"When a class overrides the equals() method it should also override the hashCode() method.All hash-based collections depend on objects meeting the equals-contract. Two equal objects must produce the same hashcode. When inheriting equals or hashcode, override the inherited and call the super method for clarification"
Functions should have clear throw statements. Functions with many throw statements can be harder to read and lead to confusion. Instead prefer to limit the amount of throw statements in a function.
This rule allows to set a list of comments which are forbidden in the codebase and should only be used during development. Offending code comments will then be reported.
This rule reports all exceptions that are caught and then later re-thrown without modification. It ignores caught exceptions that are rethrown if there is work done before that.

A class which only contains utility variables and functions with no concrete implementation can be refactored into an object or an class with a non-public constructor. Furthermore, this rule reports utility classes which are not final.
This rule detects if statements which can be collapsed.
Avoid temporary objects when converting primitive types to String. This has a performance penalty when compared to using primitive types directly. To solve this issue, remove the wrapping type.
Reports empty while expressions.
Classes which implement the Serializable interface should also correctly declare a serialVersionUID. This rule verifies that a serialVersionUID was correctly defined.
This rule reports files, classes, interfaces, objects and enums which contain too many functions. Each element can be configured with different thresholds.
Reports when Array is used. Prefer using Kotlin specialized Array Instances such as IntArray, ByteArray and so on.
This rule detects the usage of the Pair constructor to create pairs of values. Using to is preferred.
Reports class names which are forbidden per configuration.
Reports loops which contain jump statements that jump regardless of any conditions.
This rule reports public classes, objects and interfaces which do not have the required documentation.
Reports casts which are unsafe. In case the cast is not possible it will throw an exception.
This rule allows to set a list of forbidden imports. This can be used to discourage the use of unstable, experimental or deprecated APIs. Detekt will then report all imports that are forbidden.
Reports when a forEach method on ranges is used. Prefer using simple for loops.
Reports empty Kotlin (.kt) files.
Reports ranges which are empty.
Reports when very long function names are used.

Complex conditions make it hard to understand which cases lead to the condition being true or false. To improve readability and understanding of complex conditions consider extracting them into well-named functions or variables and call those instead.
Reports unused private properties, function parameters and functions.
This rule reports all cases where exceptions are thrown from a finally block. Throwing exceptions from a finally block should be avoided as it can lead to confusion and discarded exceptions.
Reports equals() methods which take in a wrongly typed parameter. Correct implementations of the equals() method should only take in a parameter of type Any?
Reports empty catch blocks.

This rule reports all exceptions of the type NotImplementedError that are thrown. It also reports all TODO(..) functions. These indicate that functionality is still under development and will not work properly. Both of these should only serve as temporary declarations and should not be put into production environments.
Exceptions should not be wrapped inside the same exception type and then rethrown. Prefer wrapping exceptions in more meaningful exception types.
Reports empty functions.

This rule detects and reports decimal base 10 numeric literals above a certain length that should be underscore separated for readability. Underscores that do not make groups of 3 digits are also reported even if their length is under the acceptableDecimalLength. For Serializable classes or objects, the field serialVersionUID is explicitly ignored.

"Turn on this rule to flag usages of the lateinit modifier.Using lateinit for property initialization can be error prone and the actual initialization is not guaranteed. Try using constructor injection or delegation to initialize properties"
Reports empty if blocks.
Reports when top level constant names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.
Reports empty init expressions.
This rule reports comments and documentation that has been added to private functions.

Reports unsafe calls on nullable types. These calls will throw a NullPointerException in case the nullable value is null. Kotlin provides many ways to work with nullable types to increase null safety. Guard the code appropriately to prevent NullPointerExceptions.
This rule reports comments and documentation above private properties.
This rule reports code that tries to print the stacktrace of an exception. Instead of simply printing a stacktrace a better logging solution should be used.
This rule reports files which do not end with a line separator.
This rule reports unnecessary braces in when expressions. These optional braces should be removed.
Reports constructor parameter names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.
This rule will report any public function which does not have the required documentation.
This rule inspects casts and reports casts which could be replaced with safe casts instead.
Reports empty when expressions.

Complex methods are hard to understand and read. It might not be obvious what side-effects a complex method has. Prefer splitting up complex methods into smaller methods that are in turn easier to understand. Smaller methods can also be named much clearer which leads to improved readability of the code.

Lambda expressions are one of the core features of the language. They often include very small chunks of code using only one parameter. In this cases Kotlin can supply the implicit it parameter to make code more concise. It fits most usecases, but when faced larger or nested chunks of code, you might want to add an explicit name for the parameter. Naming it just it is meaningless and only makes your code misleading, especially when dealing with nested functions.
Reports unreachable code.
This rule reports methods which are overloaded often.
This rule reports unnecessary parentheses around expressions. These unnecessary parentheses can safely be removed.
Reports empty secondary constructors.

“If a Kotlin file contains a single non-private class (potentially with related top-level declarations), its name should be the same as the name of the class, with the .kt extension appended. If a file contains multiple classes, or only top-level declarations, choose a name describing what the file contains, and name the file accordingly. Use camel humps with an uppercase first letter"
This rule identifies and reports properties (val) that may be const val instead. Using const val can lead to better performance of the resulting bytecode as well as better interoperability with Java.
Classes that simply hold data should be refactored into a data class. Data classes are specialized to hold data and generate hashCode, equals and toString implementations as well.
apply expressions are used frequently, but sometimes their usage should be replaced with an ordinary method/extension function call to reduce visual complexity

Reports implementations of the Iterator interface which do not throw a NoSuchElementException in the implementation of the next() method. When there are no more elements to return an Iterator should throw a NoSuchElementException.
This rule reports a member that has the same as the containing class or object.
Reports var declarations (locally-scoped variables) that could be val, as they are not re-assigned. Val declarations are assign-once (read-only), which makes understanding the current state easier.

This rule reports catch blocks for exceptions that have a type that is too generic. It should be preferred to catch specific exceptions to the case that is currently handled. If the scope of the caught exception is too broad it can lead to unintended exceptions being caught.
Reports empty classes.
Reports all calls to explicitly trigger the Garbage Collector. Code should work independently of the garbage collector and should not require the GC to be triggered in certain points in time.
This rule reports methods which have too many lines.
This rule reports class which have too many lines.
Loops which contain multiple break or continue statements are hard to read and understand. To increase readability they should be refactored into simpler loops.
Reports when variable names which do not follow the specified naming convention are used.
This rule checks for redundant visibility modifiers.
Reports empty finally blocks.
This rule detects usages of Void and reports them as forbidden. The Kotlin type Unit should be used instead. This type corresponds to the Void class in Java and has only one value - the Unit object.
检查行长度不超过指定的值。
检查一个函数体的行数不超过阈值。默认阈值为50行。
应当避免使用@throw异常。
要求宏名为全部大写字母。
要求本地变量名以小写开头（小驼峰）。
检查缩进符合指定的要求。
要求参数名以小写开头（小驼峰）。
要求类名以大写开头（大驼峰）。
要求函数名以小写开头（小驼峰）。
要求全局变量名有前缀"g"
要求方法名以小写开头（小驼峰）。
内部IP泄露。泄露的内部域名、IP等信息，将为黑客提供了明确的攻击目标与跳板。
内部仓库路径泄露。黑客一旦入侵，便可根据泄露的仓库地址，爆破出更多的项目地址，导致更加严重的敏感信息泄露。
密码泄露。泄漏的密码将会降低黑客攻击系统的难度。
内部账户泄露。黑客拿到员工账户后，在入侵前期可以定向发送钓鱼邮件等攻击，在入侵后可以尝试越权以该员工的权限在内网进行恶意操作。
内部资产配置信息泄露。内部资产特征或配置信息等可以让黑客了解到内网特征，以此来搜索更多已经泄露的敏感信息。
非开源源码泄露。代码是公司的资产，非开源源码不得对外泄漏。
内部域名泄露。泄露的内部域名、IP等信息，将为黑客提供了明确的攻击目标与跳板。
This rule reports methods which have too many lines.
Reports empty default constructors.
荷鲁斯开源组件安全检测
包含员工敏感信息(员工ID、联系方式、微信/QQ号等
包含认证凭证(各类账密、密钥、私钥证书等)
包含不和谐言论(政治、色情、辱骂等)
攻击者可能会预测移动设备标识符，然后将其用于验证，进而获取数据与服务的访问权限。

checker_desc: SSRF(Server-Side Request Forgery:服务器端请求伪造) 是一种由攻击者构造形成由服务端发起请求的一个安全漏洞。一般情况下，SSRF攻击的目标是从外网无法访问的内部系统。因为它是由服务端发起的，所以它能够请求到与它相连而与外网隔离的内部服务器系统。SSRF形成的原因大都是由于代码中提供了从其他服务器应用获取数据的功能但没有对目标地址做过滤与限制。

checker_desc: XSS攻击通常指的是通过利用网页开发时留下的漏洞，通过巧妙的方法注入恶意指令代码到网页，使用户加载并执行攻击者恶意制造的网页程序。这些恶意网页程序通常是JavaScript，但实际上也可以包括Java、 VBScript、ActiveX、 Flash 或者甚至是普通的HTML。攻击成功后，攻击者可能得到包括但不限于更高的权限（如执行一些操作）、私密网页内容、会话和cookie等各种内容。

checker_desc: OGNL是Object-Graph Navigation Language的缩写，它是一种功能强大的表达式语言，通过它简单一致的表达式语法，可以存取对象的任意属性，调用对象的方法，遍历整个对象的结构图，实现字段类型转化等功能。它使用相同的表达式去存取对象的属性。这样可以更好的取得数据。当 OGNL 表达式由外部参数未经过滤直接传入时，可能调用非授权对象的方法，导致命令执行等风险。
cov_issue_type: JAVA OGNL INJECT 漏洞检测

checker_desc: 文件上传漏洞是指由于程序员在对用户文件上传部分的控制不足或者处理缺陷，而导致的用户可以越过其本身权限向服务器上上传可执行的动态脚本文件。这里上传的文件可以是木马，病毒，恶意脚本或者WebShell等。这种攻击方式是最为直接和有效的，“文件上传”本身没有问题，有问题的是文件上传后，服务器怎么处理、解释文件。如果服务器的处理逻辑做的不够安全，则会导致严重的后果。
试图使用先前释放的资源可能会导致数据损坏、无意义的结果或运行时异常。
